addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable S
r
Francis Walsingham Knight, Principall Secretary to her Ma
tie

16 Januarie 1589 From M
r
Bodley
Buis
his opinion [Lieu] [hoh]
e intention of
e
states
in erectinge a privie Counsel about
C. Maurice
e
Counsel of state
like to be dissolved in [re], thogh in [specie] held, for colo
r
of observance of
e treatie w
th
her
Ma
tie

page.lettertext:
It may please yo
r
H. I signified in my former
What communication passed, uppon my first mee-
ting w
t
Mons
r
Bus. This day he was w
t
me
againe, and entered into further conference. In
the general assembly, whiche is held at this p
nt
by
e
States of Holland
, among other matters it wilbe
proposed, and, as he thinkes, concluded, that Count
Maurice shall have a privy councell of Hollanders
assigned, to be continually attendant uppon him:
whiche will tend in
e end to a plaine dissolution of
e Councell of state. For it should seeme by their
daily proceedinges
at they are to maintene it but for
fashions sake, and for an outward shewe of obser-
ving
e contract, wheras it is intended among them
selves, that matters of weight shall be alwaies han-
dled, a part, and in their secret assemblies.
Moreover by way of discourse he signified
further
unto me
that if her Ma
tie
shall refuse
e souveraigne pro-
tection of these contreis, and be more desirous to con-
lude a peace w
t
e
King
then to continue at thi[s]
charge, and in these termes w
t
this people, there [are]
very likely meanes to effect it, to her Ma
ties
good
liking, and
e contreis contentment. For the p
nt
state of
e Kinges affaires considered, there is no
question, in his opinion, but
at
e liberty of con-
science, and
e fruition of their privileges, w
ch
are
e principall causes
at moved these contreis to putt
themselves in armes, wilbe accorded unto them, in
as ample maner, as they have reason to reqest.
One of
e hardest pointes will consist in suborning
fitte persons, by whose interposition it may be brought
into Treaty: whiche he thinkes notw
t
standing will
be easely compassed, if her Ma
tie
be
at way inclined.
fol.39v
Belgia: 1590: Ja
n
Turn this sheet
Turn to fol 36
The late petition presented to
e King by the states
of
Artois
and
Hennault
, will
give
a great furtherance
to
e mater. For as I have heard, and as M
r
Bus
doth assure me, a speciall cause of
Richardots
errand into
Spaine
, was to persuade
e King in
their behalf to growe to a peace w
t
these
united
Provinces
: for that it was impossible for them to con-
tinue their excessive charges in these warres w
t
out
some traffique w
t
their neighbours.
Also to
e purpose of that, wherof yo
r
H. heereto
fore hath requested to be certified from me, to
witte, astouching
e affection w
ch
is borne by the
people unto
Fraunce
it may please yo
r
H to un-
derstand, that there are fower or five of
e Gene
rall states, wheruppon every good newes
at com
eth from thens send out suche speeches in their
private conventicles as if their only salvation
must come from
at kinge, and as if
ei would pre
sently fetche him hither in procession. Never
theles
e farre greater part of their Assembly, and
for ought I can perceave,
e whole Councell of state
and
e commonaltie in most places, as I learne
by Mons
r
Bus, will acknowledge no other to be
fitt for their protection but her Ma
tie
. What
badde persuasions may doe in processe of time,
w
t
an inconstant people, it is muche to be feared.
For doutles those fewe busibodies have alwaies
taken suche opposit and offensive courses to her
Ma
tie
, that they thinke their sinne to be greater
then can be pardonned, and in that respect will
doe their uttermost endevo
r
to suppresse her Ma
tie[s]
autorite in this contrey. Notw
t
st
a
ding
e report of
e messenger sent hither from
Berke
,
fol.41r
Belgia: 1590
Belgia 1590. Ja
n
16.
from fol 34
Wherof I made mention in my former,
e states are
persuaded that there is victuall in
e towne for a
longer time, and therfore use
e lesse speede in taking
any resolution. Howbeit they have dealt w
t
a mar-
chant, upon certaine conditions w
ch
are accorded
between them, who hath promised to buy a quan-
tite of Corne in
Collen
and to adventure by water
to bring it in to
e towne. Whiche they thinke will
serve
e turne to supplie their present necessitie, untill
suche time as their forces by water, wherto they have
assigned 12 shippes of warre, may be able to bring
some further reliefe. Howbeit all this
is
done w
t
out
e liking of their martiall men heere, who thinke it
unpossible to doe any good. As farre as I can
conjecture, it is rather to content them of
Guelders
,
by seeming to doe their uttermost to save
e towne,
then for any hope they conceave of good successe in
e enterprise. For it is feared
at by
e next
we shall heare
at
e Garrison hath compounded w
t
e Enemie.
Thus I take my humble leave
From
e
Hage
. Ja
n
16. 89
Yo
r
H. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
